A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.

An ideal \(\mathfrak{a}\) in a ring \(R\) is called reduced if \(\mathfrak{a} = \operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\), where \(\operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\) is the set of all elements \(a \in R\) such that there exists some \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(a^{n} \in \mathfrak{a}\).
Does the concept of a/an Noetherian ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Reduced ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a reduced ideal involves the concept of the radical of an ideal, which is defined independently of whether the ring is Noetherian or not. The radical of an ideal \\(\mathfrak{a}\\) in a ring \\(R\\) is the set of all elements \\(a \\in R\\) such that there exists some \\(n \\in \mathbb{N}\\) with \\(a^{n} \\in \mathfrak{a}\\). This definition does not require any properties related to the ascending chain condition or the finite generation of ideals, which are central to the definition of a Noetherian ring.\n\nTherefore, the concept of a Noetherian ring is not necessary for the definition of a reduced ideal to make sense. The definition of a reduced ideal can be applied in any ring, regardless of whether it is Noetherian or not. The essential aspect of the definition of a reduced ideal is the relationship between an ideal and its radical, which is a concept that can be defined in any ring setting.
